books.title: The Coming Wave
books.author: Mustafa Suleyman, Michael Bhaskar
books.blurb: Reading for perspective on AI from someone who actually built it. Suleyman co-founded DeepMind — when he talks about containment as the biggest dilemma, it's not theoretical.

books.title: The Lean Product Playbook
books.author: Dan Olsen
books.blurb: A practical guide that's helping me structure my approach to product development. The value proposition framework is something I use regularly.

books.title: The Psychology of Money
books.author: Morgan Housel
books.blurb: Room for error—that concept is rewiring how I think about money. Not about maximizing returns, but surviving the downside. Applies beyond finance too.

books.title: 10% Happier
books.author: Dan Harris
books.blurb: The 10% framing is refreshingly honest—stop chasing breakthroughs, just aim for slightly better. Small wins, compounded. Shifted how I think about progress in general.

books.title: Inspired
books.author: Marty Cagan
books.blurb: Fall in love with the problem, not the solution. Cagan's framing is simple but shifts everything about how I approach product work.

books.title: Football, Bloody Hell!
books.author: Patrick Barclay
books.blurb: The reason I wanted to get into management. Ferguson got it: you work for the fans, not the other way around. Entertain first, revenue follows. Most of today's sports has this backwards.

books.title: Wings of Fire
books.author: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam
books.blurb: Read this young, revisited in adulthood. It's the pivots that stay with me. Rejected as a pilot, he made rockets fly instead. Resilience as redirection, not just persistence.

books.title: Sapiens
books.author: Yuval Noah Harari
books.blurb: History doesn't just rhyme, it sings. Same human patterns, new wrappers. A useful lens when things seem chaotic—scratch the surface and it's familiar. Applies to people, business, everything.

books.title: The Tipping Point
books.author: Malcolm Gladwell
books.blurb: Small changes can have massive impact—no change is too small to think about. Connectors and sticky messages are my go-to lens for thinking about product adoption.

books.title: Freakonomics
books.author: Steven D. Levitt, Stephen J. Dubner
books.blurb: Everything is incentives. Once you see behavior through that lens, you can't unsee it. Useful for understanding users, teams, everything.

books.title: The Dalai Lama's Cat
books.author: David Michie
books.blurb: Lessons wrapped as comfort. The cat observes, doesn't preach—and somehow that makes the wisdom land better. A gentle way into ideas that would feel heavy anywhere else.
